Its number dates from 1922, when it was a [[New England Interstate Route]], also known as the '''Stratford-Waterbury-North Adams Route''' (for the cities the original route connected). Most of the old route in Connecticut has been upgraded to a [[freeway]] and is a major transportation link between the cities of Bridgeport and [[Waterbury (CT)|Waterbury]]. The highway has kept its number for most of its routing, and in these sections now exists as [[Connecticut Route 8]], [[Massachusetts Route 8]], and [[Vermont Route 8]]. North of [[Searsburg, VT]], the old routing exists as part of [[Vermont Route 100]] and all of [[Vermont Route 155]] (which both used to be part of VT-8). ==Route description== ===Connecticut=== {{main|Connecticut Route 8}} '''Connecticut Route 8''' begins as a freeway in the city of [[Bridgeport (CT)|Bridgeport]] co-signed with [[Route 25 (Connecticut)|Route 25]]. It has junctions with the [[Merritt Parkway]] in [[Trumbull (CT)|Trumbull]] and [[Interstate 84 (east)|Interstate 84]] in [[Waterbury (CT)|Waterbury]]. The freeway continues through the city of [[Torrington (CT)|Torrington]] up to [[US 44]] in [[Winsted, Connecticut|Winsted]]. North of Winsted, Route 8 becomes a minor rural road through [[Colebrook, Connecticut|Colebrook]] into Massachusetts. The freeway portion of Route 8 is {{convert|58|mi|km}} long. ===Massachusetts=== [[Image:Massachusetts Route 8.png|thumb|200px|Route 8 in [[Massachusetts]]]] [[Image:MA Route 8 southbound, Briggsville, Clarksburg MA.jpg|thumb|right|200px|

The entire route in Massachusetts is in [[Berkshire County, Massachusetts|Berkshire County]]. Southern terminus of VT Route 100. |} {{-}} ===Vermont=== '''Vermont Route 8''' begins in [[Stamford, Vermont]], where a [[concurrency (road)|concurrency]] with [[Vermont Route 100]] begins at the Massachusetts state line. VT Routes 8 and 100 split in [[Readsboro (VT)|Readsboro]], with VT Route 8 continuing north to end at [[Vermont Route 9]] in [[Searsburg (VT)|Searsburg]]. (VT Route 100, the original alignment of Route 8, takes a more circuitous route, heading southeast and east from the split before turning north to intersect VT Route 9 in [[Wilmington (VT)|Wilmington]].) {{VTinttop|length_ref={{cite web |url=http://www.aot.state.vt.us/Planning/Documents/TrafResearch/Publications/2006%20Route%20Log%20AADTs%20State%20Highways-Final.pdf |title=2006 (Route Log) AADTs â State Highways |month=June |year=2007 |format=PDF |publisher=[[Vermont Agency of Transportation]] | accessdate=May 17, 2009}}|county=Bennington}} {{VTint |location=Stamford |mile=0.000 |type=concur |road={{jct|state=MA|MA|8}}
{{jct|state=VT|VT|100}} |notes=Route 8 is continuation into [[Massachusetts]]; southern terminus of VT 100; southern terminus of VT 8 / VT 100 [[overlap (road)|overlap]] }} {{VTint |mile=7.945 |type=concur |road={{jct|state=VT|VT|100|dir1=north}} |location=Readsboro |notes=Northern terminus of overlap; old Route 8 continues on VT 100 }} {{VTint |mile=13.155 |road={{jct|state=VT|VT|9}} |location=Searsburg }} {{VTintbtm}} ==History== The original Route 8 began in [[Stratford, Connecticut]], running along the west bank of the lower [[Housatonic River]] until [[Shelton, Connecticut|Shelton]]. The southern end of Route 8 was relocated in 1951 to its current Bridgeport terminus as part of the freeway upgrading. The old surface road is now parts of [[Route 113 (Connecticut)|Route 113]] and [[Route 110 (Connecticut)|Route 110]]. North of Shelton, the old surface road (where it still exists) generally parallels the freeway, much of it still state-maintained. In the late 1940s, a four-lane bypass was built south of [[North Adams, Massachusetts]] and designated as [[Route 8A (Massachusetts)|Route 8A]]. Around 1975, Routes 8 and 8A were swapped, with the original route now designated as Route 8A and the bypass route as Route 8. Though the original Route 8 in Vermont did not run north of Wilmington, Route 8 was extended north to Londonderry by 1927 along present [[Vermont Route 100]], and by 1938 to [[Weston, Vermont|Weston]] and along [[Vermont Route 155]] to [[Wallingford, Vermont|Wallingford]]. This was still Route 8 in 1961, with Route 100 ending at Route 8 north of [[Weston (VT)|Weston]]. Route 100 was later extended south along Route 8 to the Massachusetts state line. The short piece of Route 8 between Weston and Wallingford became Vermont Route 155, and the Route 8 designation was assigned to its current alignment. (The piece of current Route 8 between Route 100 at [[Heartwellville, Vermont|Heartwellville]] and Route 9 at [[Searsburg (VT)|Searsburg]] had been unnumbered.)[http://docs.unh.edu/nhtopos/Wilmington.htm 1954 USGS Wilmington quadrangle][http://docs.unh.edu/nhtopos/Londonderry.htm 1957 USGS Londonderry quadrangle][http://docs.unh.edu/nhtopos/Wallingford.htm 1955 USGS Wallingford quadrangle]1961 Gousha Massachusetts-Connecticut-Rhode Island map ==See also== {{Commons category|Massachusetts Route 8}} *[[Route 8A (Massachusetts)]] - The lower segment of Route 8A is an alternate route beginning at [[Dalton, Massachusetts]] towards [[Whitingham, Vermont]] *[[Vermont Route 8A]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.state-ends.com/vermont/0080/ Vermont State Highway Termini | Vermont State Route 8] {{start srbox}} {{ct browse|previous_type=US|previous_route=7|route=[[list of Connecticut numbered highways|CT]]|next_type=Route|next_route=9}} {{ma browse|previous_type=Route|previous_route=7A|route=[[list of Massachusetts numbered highways|MA]]|next_type=Route|next_route=8A}} {{vt browse|previous_type=VT|previous_route=7A|route=[[List of Routes in Vermont|VT]]|next_type=Town|next_route=8A}} {{New England browse|previous_route=7|next_route=9}} {{s-end}} [[Category:New England Interstate Routes|08]] [[Category:Numbered routes in Massachusetts|008]] [[Category:State highways in Vermont|008]]
